title: Meet the retired oil exec plugging forgotten wells to reduce emissions

multiple-choice.question: What is an "orphan well" in the context of the oil and gas industry?

options.label: A
options.text: An oil well that is still operational but has changed ownership.

options.label: B
options.text: An oil well that has been properly sealed and abandoned.

options.label: C
options.text: An oil well that no longer has an owner and was never properly sealed.

options.label: D
options.text: An oil well that is still being drilled.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of orphan oil and gas wells in the United States?

options.label: C
options.text: 1 million

options.label: D
options.text: 2 million

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary environmental concern associated with orphan wells?

options.label: A
options.text: Oil spills

options.label: B
options.text: Methane gas leaks

options.label: C
options.text: Groundwater contamination

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the process of plugging an orphan well, and how long does it typically take?

options.label: A
options.text: It involves filling the well with cement and takes several weeks.

options.label: B
options.text: It involves removing the tubing and filling the well with cement, and typically takes two days.

options.label: C
options.text: It involves drilling a new well to intercept the orphan well, and takes several months.

options.label: D
options.text: It involves using specialized equipment to seal the well, and takes several hours.

multiple-choice.question: Who is typically responsible for plugging orphan wells?

options.label: A
options.text: The state government

options.label: B
options.text: The federal government

options.label: C
options.text: The oil and gas industry

options.label: D
options.text: Private non-profit organizations

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated cost of plugging an orphan well?

options.label: B
options.text: $30,000 to $1 million

options.label: D
options.text: $100,000 to $1 million

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the federal legislation that provides funding for plugging orphan wells?

options.label: A
options.text: The Orphan Well Act

options.label: B
options.text: The REGROW Act

options.label: C
options.text: The Infrastructure Bill

options.label: D
options.text: The Clean Energy Act

multiple-choice.question: How does the REGROW Act address the issue of orphan wells?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides funding for states to plug documented wells.

options.label: B
options.text: It requires the oil and gas industry to pay for plugging wells.

options.label: C
options.text: It establishes a national database of orphan wells.

options.label: D
options.text: It provides tax incentives for companies that plug wells.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential solution to the problem of orphan wells, according to Ira Leifer?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing funding for state plugging programs

options.label: B
options.text: Requiring the oil and gas industry to pay for plugging wells

options.label: C
options.text: Developing new technologies to seal wells

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing our dependence on oil and gas

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to locate all orphan wells, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Many wells are hidden in remote areas.

options.label: B
options.text: Records of well locations are often incomplete or inaccurate.

options.label: C
options.text: Wells can be buried underground over time.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above
